projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: His Maje≈øties PROPOSITIONS (For His Maje≈øties comming to London) Read, and Debated, in the Hou≈øe of COMMONS On Munday the 13th of November, 1648.
ALSO The Orders of the Hou≈øe of Commons in An≈øwer to the ≈øame.
WITH A Copy of a Letter from his Excellency the Lord Generall Fairfax.
And the ≈øeveral Propo≈øitions of the Army, at the Generall Councell of the Army.
Publi≈øhed for the Generall ≈øatisfaction of the whole KINGDOME.
Printed for R. Smithur≈øt, neer Pye-corner 1648,

div.head: HIS Maje≈øties Propo≈øitions and De≈øires, Read and Debated in the Hou≈øe of Commons, on Munday 13 Novem. 1648.

list.item: 1.THat his Maje≈øty may come to London, and be put into a condition of honour, freedome, and ≈øafety.
2 That his Maje≈øty may have the faith of his two Hou≈øes of Parliament, for his ≈øafety, and his Lands and Revenues to bee re≈øtored to him.
3 That his Maje≈øty may have allowance for ≈øuch part of his Revenues, as he ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe away.
4 That an Act of Oblivion may be pa≈ø≈øed for a generall Indempnity, with ≈øuch limitations as ≈øhall be agreed on by His Maje≈øty and both Hou≈øes of Parliament.

div.p: The Hou≈øe of Commons have referred it to a Committee to draw-up ≈øomething to pre≈øent for his Maje≈øties comming to London, and given In≈øtructions for the terms. His Maje≈øty being already in freedome, honour, and ≈øafety at the Treaty.

It is Ordered by the Hou≈øe of Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, That it be referred to a Committee, to con≈øider of his Maje≈øties de≈øires, concerning his Revenues, and the Parliament hath already Voted his Maje≈øty 100000 l. per annum in lieu of the Court of Wards.

Ordered by the Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, That an Act of Oblivion ≈øhall be pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty to be
pa≈ø≈øed, with ≈øuch limitations as ≈øhall be agreed on by both Hou≈øes of Parliament. And accordingly a Committee was cho≈øen to draw up a Bill for the ≈øaid Act, to be ≈øent to his Maje≈øty.

div.head: A Letter from the Lord Fairfax.

p.hi: HAving had a meeting of divers Officers of the Army, I apprehend their generall ≈øad Re≈øentment of the many pre≈ø≈øures now lying upon the Kingdom, in particular, that of free Quarter, whereby they (and the Souldiers under their Command, who have faithfully ≈øerved their Generation) are even a burden to them≈øelves, becau≈øe they are ≈øo much to the poore Country, which is the more grievous to them, becau≈øe they have generally paid their Taxes, and yet the Army not enabled to pay their Quarters, or provide them≈øelves nece≈ø≈øaries again≈øt the injury of the approaching ≈øea≈øon. I hoped ere this we ≈øhould have received ≈øome good fruit of your la≈øt being with us, the matters then agreed, being of ≈øuch publick concernment, and ≈øo much requiring expedition. I de≈øire you to improve your utmo≈øt indevour for a quicke di≈øpatch in providing effectually for the premi≈øes, to prevent tho≈øe ill con≈øequences which otherwayes delay therein may produce. I reque≈øt you to communicate this to the Hou≈øe: ≈øo hoping to hear ≈øpeedily from you, I remain

div.trailer: For the Honoured Robert Scowen E≈øq in the Chaire of the Committee for the Army.

div.head: To His Excellency, Thomas Lord Fairfax, Generall of all Forces rai≈øed by the Parliament, in the Kingdome of England, and Dominion of Wales.
The humble Petition of the Officers and Souldiers in Gol. Fleetwoods, Col. Whalies, and Col. Bark≈øteads Regiaments, under your Excellencies Command.
div.p:
THat through the ble≈ø≈øing of God upon the Army, under your Excellencies Conduct, the enemies of this Nations
Peace and Freedom, have been twice ≈øubdued.

That as we ingaged in Judgment and Con≈øcience again≈øt them, to pre≈øerve this Nation from ≈ølavery, ≈øo we hope the Parliament (by whom we were invited to ingage) would have executed Ju≈øtice, upon the publike and grand Enemies thereof, and immediately have ≈øetled a ju≈øt Government, under which every mans freedom, right & propriety might have been pre≈øerved

That your Petitioners had ≈øome hope of that happy fruit of their labours, hazard and expence of blood, when the Parliament voted no more addre≈ø≈øes to the King, and hereupon your Excellency and your Petitioners did te≈øtifie their approbation of tho≈øe Votes, and did ingage to adhere, and ≈øtand by them, in the ≈øettlment of the Nation without, & again≈øt the King, or any other that ≈øhould partake with him, & your Excellency & your Petitioners received the thanke of both Hou≈øes for the ≈øame.

That notwith≈øtanding a bloody War hath been ≈øince rai≈øed by the Prince his Commi≈ø≈øion, a forraigne Nation invited to (which did) invade us (and as there is ground to beleeve) by the Kings con≈øent, thereby to inflave us, to his exorbitant will and lu≈øt,
Yet when through the great mercy and favour of God, all their forces were ≈øuppre≈øt, in≈øtead of having our expectations an≈øwered (as to a ju≈øt ≈øettlement) we find.

That the wicked and bloody de≈øignes of the Enemies of this kingdome ≈øtill continue, As of that of Ireland by Ormond, and that at home, threatning the lives of every wel-affected per≈øon. And this we humbly conceive they are the more imboldned unto, becau≈øe of the prevalency of ≈øome in greate≈øt Authority, that will let no Ju≈øtice be don upon the grand fomentors, contrivers and actors, in the fir≈øt and late Warre. So that the Innocent blood of many of our dear friends (that hath been ≈øpilt) the rapines, robberies, burning and ≈øpoiling many welaffected towns and per≈øons, of all livelihood, is forgotten, ju≈øt Government ≈øubverted, and ≈øuch petitions tending to a ≈øetling of a ju≈øt & equall Government, (as that of the 12 of Septem. la≈øt, from the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter) ≈øleighted, the intolerable burthen of free Quarter ≈øtill continued, no redre≈ø≈øe of publick grievances, by rea≈øon of which the implacable malice of our twice
conquered Enemies, ≈øeems to ≈øteal credit in the hearts of many) who≈øe weaknes hinders them from di≈øcerning their evill ends) ≈øo that their bloody intentions again≈øt the well-affected in this Nation, doth begin to manife≈øt it ≈øelfe, both again≈øt Parliament men and the Army, as is apparent by that mo≈øt de≈øperate and inhumain murthering of Col. Rainsborough.

That we conceive, your Excellency and the Army, next under God, are the only Bar, that lyeth in their way, hindring the accompli≈øhing of their ends: ≈øo their main de≈øign is, how to de≈øtroy you and it. And that they endeavour by continuing us on free quarter, yet providing Ordinances, again≈øt it, and In≈øtructions to enter into no mans hou≈øe (except Innes, Ale-hou≈øes, & Taverns) again≈øt their wills, which was by us joyfully excepted, that thereby the Country might be ea≈øed of that devouring Creature Free-Quarter, yet when the Army was thus quartered for the ea≈øe of the Country, we were content to make hard ≈øhift to maintaine our ≈øelves out of our pay though it was ≈ømall, 2 s. per diem for hor≈øe, and 8 d. for foot, but that through the ≈øubtilty of our Enemies, hath been kept from us, we having not received any pay in ≈øix months together. So that we mu≈øt either ≈øtarve and lye in the ≈øtreets, or el≈øe ≈øtill oppre≈ø≈øe the Country by Free-Quarter, which renders us odious to the people. And it cannot be otherwi≈øe, ≈øeeing the A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øements of 60000 l. per men≈øem, if it were all a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and gathered (be≈øides mony for providing Armes for the Hor≈øe and Foot, Recruit Hor≈øes, Ammunition for the Army and Garri≈øons, Clothes, Stockings, Shooes for Foot Souldiers, and other incident Charges) will not amount to the Per≈øonall
Pay of the Army by 12000 lib. per men≈øem.

Now we being pre≈ø≈øed in our judgements, by our Enemies helli≈øh and Bloudy de≈øignes; and their in≈øolent and barbarous Carriage, and al≈øo our hearts burthened with the un≈øetled condition of this poor Kingdom, are bold to pre≈øent to your Excellencies con≈øideration the≈øe things following.

list.item: 1. That ≈øpeedy and impartiall Ju≈øtice may be executed upon all fomenters, contrivers, and actors in the fir≈øt and late War.
2. That Inqui≈øition be made for the bloud of Rainsborough.
3. That the ≈øupream power may be declared and determined, that the want thereof may not bee the ground of future, (as it hath been of the≈øe former) Wars.
4. That a period may be ≈øet for this pre≈øent Parliment to end as ≈øoon as may be with ≈øafety, and provi≈øions made for future Parliaments to meet certain without writ or ≈øumons
5. That rules may be ≈øet down between the People and their Repre≈øentatives.
6. That Laws may be made in things civill to bind all men, ≈øo that men in no ca≈øe of offence, may be freed from the Law whereunto another is ≈øubject.
7. That all tho≈øe common grievances and de≈øires in our Declarations of June 14. and June 23. 1647. and expre≈ø≈øed in the London Petition, be ≈øpeedily granted and redre≈ø≈øed.
8. That pre≈øent provi≈øion be made for con≈øtant pay of the Army.

9. That the Arrears due from the 14. of Ianuary, may bee paid off, before we be commanded to pay Quarters, and that there may be no other abatement from Officers or Souldiers for free quarter, then according to the rates ≈øet downe in the Ordinance of Parliament, of the 14. day of December la≈øt.
10. That the Country may be paid for our free quarter, according to the Deduction out of our pay out of their A≈ø≈øe≈øments.

11. That in as much as the A≈ø≈øe≈øments fall ≈øhort to pay the Army; That therefore there may be Additionall ≈øupplies out of the E≈øtates of the old and new Delinquents, that there bee
no more Tax or Charge to the Common-wealth.
12. That forthwith an account be called for from all per≈øons that have been betru≈øted with any thing for the State, that the Kingdom may be ≈øatisfied therein.
13 That the Deanes and Chapters Lands may be given to pay the Souldiers Arrears, ≈øeeing the Parliament have given away the Delinquents E≈øtates that ≈øhould have done it.

div.p: The≈øe things being the proper i≈ø≈øue of our ≈øerious thoughts, we implore your Excellency through the many ble≈øsings, deliverances, victories and ≈øucce≈ø≈øes, the Lord hath crowned you withall, The dangers you have been pre≈øerved from, the mi≈øeries of this bleeding Nation, the blood of the innocent, the outcry of the Widdow, and Fatherle≈ø≈øe, the ≈øad omen of future troubles, to con≈øider the nece≈ø≈øity of attaining the≈øe things, that we may be no longer the ≈øcorn and contempt of the Nation, nor object of our Enemies malice, by the want of ju≈øt peacce and ≈øettlement; but with an undaunted courage, to de≈øire the Parliament that the≈øe things may be forthwith e≈øtabli≈øhed, that w ‚Ä¢ may with ≈øafety be relea≈øed, from this trouble≈øome and hazardous imploiment, which by rea≈øon of the grivous oppre≈ø≈øion thereof, we profe≈ø≈øe we are weary of which things we challenge as ours and the Kingdoms due, twice bought with our blood. In the doing which your Excellency ≈øhal not fail of their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance who are ready to wade through a Sea of troubles, to have them e≈øtabli≈øhed, though they peri≈øh in the work.
